document.text: Work is progressing well on the new Ited House Volunteer Fire Department building, and, according to a spokesman, if all goes as planned, the depart ment could be in service by next fall. Bill Austin, chief of the RHFD, says the building which will house the departments vehicles and equipment should be completed by May of this year. He ndtes that there are still many details which must be tended to before the new volunteer fire department may go into service,, however. Oat biggest problem is that we still peed a lot of equipm ent, notes A ustin. Austin says the volunteers need coats, helmets, boots, air packs, portable pumps, hoses, nozzles, various small . tools such as axes and spanner wrenches to tighten hose nozzles, radio equipment, and sirens. The radio equipment, which will be the departments most expensive equipment exclud ing the vehicles, will include a central monitoring unit and individual monitoring units for the members. Austin says the Red House Fire Department .will be monitored through the Charlotte Court House Sheriffs Department. Austin adds that a fire department siren will be placed somewhere in the village. But all this equipment is still needed before the volunteers can begin fighting fires, adds Austin. The RHFD was organized in August of 1979 by the late Len Elder, who also made a 10,000 contribution to the department shortly before his death this year. Those funds were used to get started on the building which will house the fire equipment. The department owns two firefighting trucks, a Chevrolet and a LaFrance, currently being kept at Austins home, and in the barn of Melvin

document.text: William Anderson Andy Scr uggs, 68, died at 840 .m. Tuesday in Lynchburg General Hospital. Born in Buckingham County, he was a son of the late Willie Alexander Scruggs and Bessie Wright Scruggs. He was a member of Memorial United Methodist Church, and was retired after 27 years of service with the Department of State Police. He was a charter member and. current president of the Appomat tox Volunteer Rescue Squad, and was retired after 80 years of service with the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. He if survived by his wife, Mildred Lawson Scruggs, one daughter, Bettie S. Magann one son, William David Scruggs and three grandchildren, all of Appo mattox three brothers, Wilbur A. That takes an hour, so they leave en route to Appomattox at 9 a.m. They arrive at the Liberty Baptist Church around 11 a.m. They have tp unload and set up for donorsnd that takes another hour so they really have to rush to make it by noon. Due to  this schedule, you know they have not had time for any lunch, so, about 1 p.m., the staff takes turns going out for lunch. This takes a little time and may cause a short delay but we hope not long, especially since they have a new process now and you are not on the table as long. Now we come to the close of the visit - 6 p.m. Again they are packing up and loading takes about 30 to 45 minutes and then they have the drive back to Roanoke. Ford, Jr. to collect Christmas donations for the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. These public spirited volun teers dedicate long hours of their time in service to the community without any material compensation. Not only do they attend fires both in the Towpr and County but they hold many training sessions in order to become more proficient. Theirs is a time and energy consuming activity and is an essential service to the whole community. This will give you the opportunity to say thank you by donating when Mr. -Drinkard or Mr. Ford contacts you sometime during the month of November.

document.text: Three-year-old Ralph Tyree and his 15 -month-old brother, Bobby Tyree died in a house fire at their home, Route 1, Gladstone early Saturday morn ing, March 4. Their mother, Mrs. Shirley Tyree, 19, was first taken to Lynchburg General Hospital for treatment of burns r e c e i v e d when she tried to rescue her children. She was later t r a n s  ferred to the Medical College of Virginias burn center in Rich mond where her condition was said to be satisfactory. The Gladstone Volunteer Fire Department was joined by the Amherst Volunteer Fire De partment and two Monelison fire trucks in efforts to control the flames consuming the one-story frame home of Mr. and Mrs. W. Fitch Tyree, Jr. Mrs. Tyree was taken to Lyn chburg General Hospital by the Gladstone Rescue Squad ambu lance. The volunteers from the three departments fought the flames for two hours, hauling water from Route 60 over a quarter mile stretch of unimproved gra vel road, before they were able to retrieve the bodies of the two infants from the rubble.

document.text: There will be a Christmas Parade in Appomattox on Fri day night, December 1st, at 630 p.m., according to an announcement from J. Frank lin Vaughan, President f tl?e  Chamber of Commerce of Appomattox County. The parade will begin at the Fidelity National Bank Hillcrest Branch, and will go down Court Street to Main Street, stopping on Main Street for Santa Claus to greet the children. Santa Claus, of course, will1 be the main feature of the parade and he will have candy for all children, compliments of the Jaycees of Appomattox County. Leading the parade will be the Appomattox County High School Marching Band and Majorettes. Also participating in the parade will be local Scout Troops, Woodmen of the World Drill Team, a Shriners Clown Group from Lynchburg, FFA Float, American Legion Marching Group, Appomattox County Rescue Squad, Appo mattox Volunteer Fire De partment, Gladstone Rescue Squad, Concord Rescue Squad, Concord Volunteer Fire De partment and the Pamplin Volunteer Fire Department. All persons and organiza tions interested in entering a float or participating in the parade are asked to contact Jim Pugh, Jr., at the Farmers National Bank.

document.text: The Woodmen of the World Camp 71 and Lodge 8073 held their annual awards night on Dec. 3. Cecil W. Deaner, president of Camp 71, served as master of ceremonies. The Outstanding Citizenship Award was presented to Gordon H. Bragg on behalf of the Woodmen. The presentation was made by Bradley L. Babcock, head baseball coach at James Madison University. . The presentation reflected on tne many experiences shared by Coach Bragg and his former students. Mrs. Bragg and daughters, Margaret, Kathy and Patty were present for the surprise presentation. President Margie Reider of Lodge 6073 and Gregg Martin of Camp 71 presented a total of 52,400 in equipment to the following civic organizations Red House Volunteer Fire Department, Gladstone Rescue Squad, Appomattox Rescue Squad, Pamplin Volunteer Fire Department and Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. R,B. Moore, jurisdictional president, presented a 50-year membership pin to Mr. Horace Shirey. The Conservation Award was presented to David M. Smith on behalf of Camp 71 by Warren E. Taylor, member of Camp 71. Warren reflected on the many years of conservation observed and taught by David while working for the Division of Forestry, Due to a recent sickness, David could not be present. His wife, Bessie C. Smith, accepted the plaque for her husband. Harry E. Ranson, past president of Camp 71, presented Margie D. Reider the Woman of Woodcraft Award for 1983. This is the most prized sward given any member of the focal lodges.

document.text: The wild and wooly west has no thing on Virginia when it comes to roundin up livestock after it has been turned out to pasture for a year. Only in Virginia they round em up in the summertime, and the stock isnt sheep or cattle, but ponies, real wild ones, too. This year the annual roundup sets in on Chincoteague Island, a part of Eastern Shore, July 29 and lasts through July 30, two full days of riding and rounding up these ponies, according to the State Con servation Commission. This annual event is sponsored by .he Chincoteague Volunteer Fire Department and is held in conjunc ión with its annual carnival, which tdds to the fun and excitment of the .vhole affair. The wild ponies of Chincoteague have made that section of Eastern. Shore familiar to the nation and famous to the world, and visitors from distant lands are common. ISvery year about this time the men jf Chincoteague Island come to Assateague, the area in which the ponies are really located, for the wild pony roundup. These little animals are spotted, corraled and driven to gether on the beach and at low tide are brought over to Chincoteague Island, some 200 yards of water away, where they are herded into enclosures awaiting the annual pony sale. During the remaining of the year the refuge manager of Chincoteague keeps a watchful eye on the stock of animals on the island, allowing them to multiplly and graze on the refuge without interference by man, ac cording to the Virginia Travel Coun cil. Just how the ponies ever got to this island is uncertain and is still shrouded by mystery, tall tales and legend. Some are of the opinion that they swam ashore after a shipwreck near the island others believe they belonged to a band of pirates who failed to recover their animals after allowing them to graze. Those interested in learning more about the wild ponies couid drop a line to the Chief of the Chincoteague Volunteer Fire Department, Chinco teague Virginia,

document.text: The Town of Appomattox held its annual Christmas on Monday evening at Jeannes Steak House. Town officials, all town employees and invited guests were present to honor members of the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. The volunteer firemen are honored each year for their service to the town and to the county and a bonus check is given to each of the volunteers, this year the largest amount ever. In the photo above, left to right, are James Ford, Town Police Chief, who assisted in collecting money for the gift C. R. Skinny Wooldridge, Fire Commirtr - Slick Mitchell, Fire Chief and Paul Drinkard, Chairman of the Committee to solicit contriDuuou ior the firemen. Drinkard and Ford were each presented a gift of appreciation from members of the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department.

document.text: The Pennsylvania State Capitol at Harris burg was totally destroyed by fire Tuesday. Tbe loss will be gl, 000,00a Tbe Insurance it comparatively small, about 0100,003. Sev eral persons were slightly but not seriously Injured in fighting the flames. A new and much more handsome State building, it is said, will beereoted at once. The session of the Legislature will continue at Harrisburg, although it was stated at first that both Sen ate and House would hold their future meet ings during this session in either Philadel phia or Pittsburg, to both of which they were Invited when the destructive character of the fire became known. The Senate wilt meet In tbe Supremo courtroom and the House will meet In a room on tha seoond floor of tbe posteffice building. Governor Hastings la expected to send a message to tbe Legislature Immediately in referenoe to tbe destruction of the. capltol building and recommending Immediate ac tion on the part ot th Legislator with a view to the restoration ot th capltol build ing. The volunteer fire department ot Harris burg Is held partly to blame for the rapid spread of th flames because of its alleged tardiness in responding to the fire alarms When the fir was first discovered the House of Delegates was in session and th. Senate was about to convene after a few minutes recess. Smoke was seen In email volumes pouring out lute the Capltol grounds from th House window. The members were not mindful of It until the great elouda rolled by the window. In stantly there was a motion to adjourn and all was oonstarnatlon. The Senate chamber was crowded with members Senator John O. Grady, ot Philadelphia, warned the Sena tors, and there was a general hustle to re move effects. Fire alarms were sent In and soon the Senate was a mass of howling men. Desks were hastily carried out Th same work was done in the Hous chamber. The departments In the burned building were tbe following Senate and House, all ot tbe committee rooms, the Senate librarians room, Sonata ehlef olerks room, smoking- room, barber shop In Senate, Lieutenant- Governors room, room of President pro tern., school department, House chief clerks room, Speaker of Houses room, resident clerks room, two telegraph offices, room of tbe Har risburg Legislative Correspondents Associa tion, pasters and folders departments, cloak rooms of both brahobes and th engine- rooms. Superintendent of Public Buildings De laney places the loss at 1,500,000.  I will, said he,  contend for the rebuilding on tho colonial style. We will have a meeting of the building committee a soon as theJHouse and Senate committees can he appointed, There is not much over 100,00 Insurance on tha building and contents, according to the statement of the treasury officials. There was 400,000 on tha cspttol building while the State library was in It. After it was re moved to another structure the Insurance on tbe legislative halls was reduced to 60,000. In addition to this there Is 123,000 insur ance carried on all tbe State buildings. The State oapltol was a plain but substan tial brick building, the cornerstone of which was laid seventy-eight years ago. The orig inal tract of four acres for tbe capltol build ings was a donation from John Harris,-the founder of Harrleburg. Subsequently ten acres and five lota adjoining were bought by th State for 2,100, a small portion ot this land being resold in 1828 for 412. Thus It will be scan that the orlglual tract of land only cost the State 1,688. The construction of the capltol buildings cost  135,000, the cor nerstone being laid In 1819, and tbe first Leg islature meeting in It In 1822. When the cor nerstone of the capltol was laid by Governor Findlay, In 1819, ho broke bis mallet In per forming the ceremonies, which was consid ered by many a bad omen.

document.text: The Pamplin Volunteer Fire Department provided Pamplin Elementary School kindergarten and first grade students with a closer look at a fire engine on Tuesday. October. 7. The activity was planned by Ms. Dianne Henderson, K teacher, and Mrs. Donna Terry, teachgc of the first grade, in connection with Fire Prevention Week. Mr. Herman Richardson brought the fire engine to the school for a demonstra tion that students found exciting and informative. document.text: The Pamplin Ruritan Club held their regular meeting Jan. 11, in the high school with a large attendance. Dinner was served by the teachers and patrons of the fifth, sixth and seventh grades. President Eugene Sears presided at the meeting. Reports were given and minutes read of the December meeting by William Hix, secretary. The guest speaker for the evening was A. H. Hamilton Jr., fire chief of the Volunteer Fire Department of Drakes Branch. Two of the club members Edward Ranson and William Hix, will attend the Ruritan National Convention at Ashville, N. C., Jan. 27, 28, and 29.

document.text: The Concord Volunteer Fire Department will hold its annual carnival Friday April 24 at the Concord Elementary School. Supper will be served from 5-8 p.m. with a menu consisting of ham, turkey witf gravy and dressing, candied yams, butter- beans, coffee, tea, homemade rolls and choice of dessert. Prices for the meal are adult plate with one meat, 3 adult plate with two meats, 3.50 and childs plate one meat, 2.00. The snack bar will open at 6 p.m. as well as other activities including a cake walk, country store, parcel post, fish pond, basketball throw, dunking tank, bingo and space walk. A dance featuring music by The Waysiders will begin at 830 in the cafeteria. Various items will be auctioned off in the auditorium starting at 10 p.m. This is the only fund-raising event the fire department sponsors during the year. Proceeds, after deducting ex penses, will go toward opera tion of the department and paying for the new fire engine.

document.text: The Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department has reported answering 88 calls in 1975, an increase of 20 calls over the previous yehr. Volunteer firemen spent 650 manhours answering the calls 66 of which were in the county 22 in the Town-of Appomattox, In answer to the calls, they travelled approximately 1500 miles. In the coming year, the Fire Department plans to subnut either weekly or jnonthlj reports of activities. Read about them in the TIMES-VIR GINIAN.

An unsuccessful at tempt by burglars to enter the big vault in the office of the Southern Dry Goods Company, on North Union treet was discovered when employes reported for work. Thè hlbges on the vault doors had been sawed in two, but the cracksmen were foiled in their attempts to enter the vault by a steel bar across the inside of the doors. Lynchburg.Hallie G. Witt, who served as a sergeant , in the casualty department of the Fifty-fourth Depot Brigade during the war, following an enlistment with Company G, First Vir ginia Infantry, has been elected first lieutenant of Company E, First Vir ginia National Guard here. He suc ceeds J. O. Jordan, recently trans ferred to a Roanoke Machine Gun Company, of which he has been made captain. Pulaski.  Fire of undetermined origin gutted the millinery and music departments of the store of Clyde Smith  Son. Nothing was saved from either department. A partition separated thsm from the main floor. The Arm carried about a 20,000 stock, with only Insurance of 1,000, with 500 on the building. Effective work of the volunteer fire department pre vented a section of the town being burned. Newport News.A resolution in dorsing the action of the local school board in putting a bau on dancing by high school pupils was adopted by the Ministerial Association. The resolu tion declared that the dance craze has proven one of the most distressing results of the World War, and that thoughtful people on both sides of the Atlantic are moving so unitedly to oppose it that even the dance masters are advocating reform and advertising a change of policy. Petersburg.George Lundy, son of Chesterfield County Magistrate G. E. Lundy, whose trial in the Hustings Court of this city in November on the charge of shooting and killing Clyde James at the Lundy home on the night of November 11, resulted in a hung jury, pleaded guilty to voluntary man slaughter, and was sentenced by Judge Mullen to one year in the State Peni tentiary. Lundy will be taken to Rich mond within the next few days to be gin serving his sentence. Dantfile.That, a point in Virginia is being considered as the terminal in a cross-Atlantic zeppelin service was asserted by Colonel A. B. Carrington of this city who recently returned from Europe. He said he had been assured that capitalists of France, America and England werd forming a company to operate zeppelins and heavier-than- air machines as soon as commercial flying has reached a point where it can be Undertaken on a large scale. He said a point slightly ndrth of Dan ville, Va., was under consideration, and that he had pledged the interest of his community in any such scheme, even proffering 190 acres for the land ing place. Danville.The campaign tor mem bers will be continued by the Virginia Tobacco Growers Association through out the month of January. This an nouncement was made here by W. It. Ogg, secretary treasurer of the organ ization, who is directing the campaign. The oampaign was scheduled to be completed by January 1, but owing to a number of circumstances this was found to .be inadvisable. Many coun ties were unable to get their county organizations perfected and organizers put in the field until the middle of December. The combining of the three Virginia tobacco growers organiza tions was also a large factor in chang ing the plans for the membership campaign. The condition of the roads has also hindered organization work in many communities. Fredericksburg.At a meeting of citizens of Spottsylvania county the organization of a Spottsylvania Coun ty Good Roads Association was effect ed by the election of Captain M. B. Rowe as chairman, and T. E. Thomas as secretary and treasurer. Sub-chair men will be named for the different districts in the county and an inten sive drive will be put on for member ship in the Virginia Good Roads Asso ciation to develop sentiment for better highways and make possible good roads educational work in every sec tion of the State. Petersburg.A large frame build ing at Camp Lee, formerly the colored hostess house, now used by Captains J. E. Allison and W. A. Rawls, of the Forty-third Infantry, and their fam ilies as quarters, was destroyed by fire, causing a loss of about 13,000. Origin of the fire is not known, but the build ing was a complete loss. None of the household effects were saved, the fam ilies barely escaping without injury with no clothes other then those they wore.

document.text: Mrs. Robert A . Eagle , 1 M rs. Frances Templeton Eagle, 56, 4829 Tyreeanna Road, died at 1110 a.m . Wednesday in Lynchburg Ge neral Hospital. She was the wife of Robert Asa Eagle. Born in Bedford County, she was a daughter of the late Tommie Lou and Mary Jones Tem pleton. She was past president of Concord Volunteer Fire Department Auxiliary, a member of Tyreeanna Exten sion Homemakers Club and Tyreeanna United Methodist Church. In addition to her husband, she is survived by a son, R. Stanley Eagle, and a daughter, Cheryl L . Eagle, both of Lynchburg a brother, Curtis T. Templeton, Lynchburg four sisters, Lois T. Tomlinson and Mary Ellen T. Willoughby, both of Lynchburg, Ethel T. Manley. Big Island, and Christine T. Campbell, Evington, and a granddaughter,  Tracy Lynn Eagle, Lynchburg.  Funeral services were con ducted at 1 p.m. Friday in Whitten Park Avenue Chapel by the Rev. Samuel - McGee. Burial was in Spring Hill Cemetery. Whitten Park Avenue Chapel was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Mayor S. R. Lawson Monday night reported to the Town Council that excavation for the two acre sewage lagoon is al most complete. Two members of the Appomat tox Volunteer Fire Department appeared before the Council to ask for consideration of a new building to house equipment and a meeting place. C. R. Skinney Wooldridge and Dick Bass said they had located a piece of land the Bledsoe property and that seller, S. L. Lawson, had named a reasonable price. They said they would need a four stall building, plus upstairs area, and that one of the four stalls could be used as a wash pit. Council requested that they obtain tentative plans and an idea of how much such a build ing will cost. Mrs. W. W. Burke appeared before Council to review the work done by the RAD Centenn ial subcommittee and the sub sequent development of Appo mattox Heritage, Incorporated. We feel we have a unique story to tell, she said, in des cribing the proposed Sound - Light production for the Sur render Grounds. In a Sound- Light production, there are no live characters, she explained, and no screen to watch. While the story is being told via tape recording, lights are turned on in various buildings, or field areas are lit to reenact historical events. She said that a contribution by Council now would make it poss ible to bring Dr. Gordon Graham here to draw up plans for the production and to work full time on a job that has become too big for the volunteer help given thus far. Graham, she said, would act as executive di rector, but would be under the direct control of the board of directors of Appomattox Heri tage, Inc. Among other things being done in the sound-light planning, she said, is a survey of motel and hotel accomodations in a thirty mile radius. Dr. Lawson said that success ful production at the Park will be one of the biggest boons to this town in the last 109 years. Council voted to donate 500 hive west and reach I to Appomattox Heritage, Inc.

document.text: Mayor H. B. Pack has designated November as Volunteer Firemens Month and has authorized James R. Ford, Jr. and Paul Drinkard, pictured above, to collect Christmas dona- time for the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. These public spirited volunteers dedicate long hours of their time in service to the community without any material compensation. Not only do they attend fires both in the town and County but they hold many training sessions in order to become more proficient. Theirs is a time and energy consuming activity and is an essential service to the whole community. This will give you the opportunity to say Thank you by donating when Mr. Drinkard or Mr. Ford contacts you sometime during the month of November.

document.text: mattox held the annual banquet for the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department members on Mon day evening, December 18, 1972, at Jeannes Steak House. Over fifty persons attended the dinner at which time Christmas bonus checks were presented to each of the volun teer firemen, compliments of the citizens of Appomattox County. Dick Bass, Fire Chief, thanked Mayor Pack and members of the council for the delicious dinner and thanks went to Paul Drinkard and James Ford for their efforts in collecting the cash donations from citizens of the county for the nice Christmas bonus checks given each of the volunteer firemen. He reported that the Fire Department had responded to 51 calls during the year with approximately seven men an swering each call. Immediately following the dinner, the Town Council met in the town office at 800 p.m. for their monthly business ses sion. Mayor Henry Pack presided and all members were in at tendance. Ivey Holland, Chairman of the Budget and Finance Com mittee, reported that his com mittee had been meeting and had prepared copies of the proposed budget for members of the council. The total of the proposed budget for 1973 amounted to 116,390.00. A motion that the proposed budget be accepted was made by Ivey Holland, se conded by Robert Hubbard and the council voted to accept the budget as presented. A copy of the budget will be published in the TIMES-VIRGINIAN at a later date. The total of the budget for

document.text: LABOR SURVEY SET FOR school in the Fall, trips were arranged to Coles Diary, toe Appomattox Post Office, Farm ers Bank, Fidelity Bank, Har old Stratton and Charlie Lewis farms, and toe Lynchburg Muni cipal Airport. Resource per sons who visited the classrooms were Howard Gregory, Virginia State Police, and members of the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department. Mrs. Lena Mc Lean, school nurse, came to school to allow the students to meet her and hear about clinic room care. The Parent Visitation Day was held on July 21, when 76 adults visited the classrooms, had juice break with their chil dren, and attended a meeting at which they heard information about the structure of the sum mer session and organizational procedures of the regular ses sion. The non-graded approach to instruction includes intro ducing new materials as the development of the childs skills indicated the need.
